font-size="8.733101039135507px" fill="#1e1e1e" text-anchor="start" style="white-space: pre;" direction="ltr" dominant-baseline="alphabetic">Proposed solution that </text><text x="0" y="19.24775469025466" font-family="Nunito, sans-serif, Segoe UI Emoji" font-size="8.733101039135507px" fill="#1e1e1e" text-anchor="start" style="white-space: pre;" direction="ltr" dominant-baseline="alphabetic">you think goes to X but leads to Y</text></g></svg>

Ask for help to achieve your desired outcome, not what you *think* will lead to your desired outcome. Your premise may be wrong, which will waste the efforts of all involved. (Source: [The XY Problem](https://xyproblem.info/) via Odin Project)

[[Learn in Public/Think/Solving for Y when you want X may lead to wasted time\|Solving for Y when you want X may lead to wasted time]].

> [!tip] Solving for X instead 
> Dana: My gel nails are coming off after only 3 days. I want them to last longer. Help please? ðŸ˜£
> Gemma: There could be a few reasons why. What are you doing? ðŸ™‚ 
> Dana explains her steps. 
> Gemma: Ah, you've forgotten to cap the free edge! Easy fix. 
> Result: problem solved

[**Prev**:: [[(15C) Prefer to write modular code to simplify future projects\|(15C) Prefer to write modular code to simplify future projects]]]

Proposed solution that 
you think goes to X but leads to Y
